Babcock Canada - This is the most two-tier structured company I've ever worked - there is one rule for the executives and senior management, and one for everyone else. This wouldn't be so frustrating, but the company has a huge surplus of 'senior managers' and 'directors' and 'vice presidents' that don't actually seem to DO anything.

This varies by department - according to the org chart, one department has 4 directors and 3 employees (Business Dev) while other departments don't seem to have any executives (mainly the various support departments who are left to fend for themselves at the table)

The 'executive' class seems to get all kinds of lovely bonuses (personal trips, huge bonuses etc), while everyone else has to cut costs constantly. 

Every team is in it's own little silo while middle-managers fight to stake a bigger claim for themselves. Virtually no inter-department communication.

headline: Terrible Employer Despite the Benefits
pros:
The people are for the most part excellent.

The benefits are solid. The pay is decent but still below industry average.
cons:
As of 2019, Babcock Canada offers little in the way of career progression or opportunities for growth. Maybe within some teams close to the project, but certainly not in the wider organization. 

The pay banding that has been introduced is all over the map, and has left many people dissatisfied. I tried for more than a year to get my banding adjusted, with support from my direct supervisor, and nothing happened. I quit for another employer and now I hear that (as I expected) my old position has been posted at a higher pay level.

This sort of disrespect for personnel is rampant, and it seems to be common for people to earn less than the newcomers they’re training. It’s also pretty common knowledge that Babcock’s closest partner, Victoria Shipyards, pays roughly 10% higher wages than Babcock and they also have larger bonuses for their staff.

headline: Probably the worst one out of the Big 4s in Perth
pros:
Hard to generalise when we talk about the Big 4 machines. The practice could be run very differently in another city in the same country. My feedback is based on what I saw in EY Perth Advisory/Consulting world. 
> Knowledge-base is pretty good and accessible.
> Overall, not too bad a place if you want a start/local experience (important in Perth market) but stay too long and it's suffocating.
cons:
Too many to call out here but here's some main ones:
> Partners too greedy to look at staff's plight when on projects.
> People with job titles below Manager are treated quite poorly. No attention given to their feedback/input.
> Groupism and favouritism quite rampant in Perth with little support for "outsiders".
> I've seen things go worse for racial minorities with stupid things such English language skills, Accent etc. brought into conversations when discussing performance and feedback.
> Enjoy milking their clients for non value add, redundant projects staffed with absolute newbs. E.g. Mining clients served by nuffy directors and senior managers who've never ever seen a mine in their life.
> They make sure to make life miserable for people on bench with meaningless proposals for projects EY has no chance/expertise/skills/offering. Often, only aim is to undercut the competition.

My experience with some colleagues has been great, there are some fantastic people working for EY, but the difference between the culture reputation and culture reality is shockingly vast, and overall experience has been pretty appalling.

headline: Good on the outside, not great after a while."
pros: The people. You meet some great people and hear interesting things about thier lives and work. Co workers also very friendly and nice but very young.
cons:
This list goes on. Theres no potential for growth unless youre comitted to working at the very same hotel for longer than 10 years.
Not only that but getting a raise is next to impossible. Starting at 8.50 i thought was great, Im very young and live by myself so it paid the bills and then i had a little money left. But the work was alot more than i expected for that pay. You're not just front desk. Youre also a housekeeper, room checker, if a tv is broken you have to see if you can fix it, you take things to rooms for needy guests, you negotiate constantly, us night auditors have to cook breakfast and clean the halls and lobby...Im not one to complain about hard work but when other hotels pay $10-11 an hour to do the same stuff the motivation is lowered significantly.
No bennefits -  and dont even get hurt on the job. A minor papercut or worse burn from cooking breakfast management tries to skimp anywhere they can just so you dont have to file for workers comp. I got burned from the coffee machines hot water tap, the standing GM did not want to hear about it. Luckly it healed in a good three hours.
The management is very nice but wont work with you at all. I started part time as a night auditor, then i asked if i could  start full time on the morning and afternoon shifts. Although i was promised nothing i kept asking and proving myself only to be told "Oh we will get you on the day shift as soon as we can..." Its been two months and im still full time night. My body cant do it and my weight is dropping because i cant keep a normal eating scheduel. Also its apparently difficult for them to make a scheduel because sometimes id be called in to work after planning my days off only to be told they made a mistake and ment to put me on. 
If you want to move up, you are going to be let down by their expectations and ability to train you.

job_title: IBM GBS Consulting By Degrees Entry Level Consultant
headline: Rather underwhelmed
pros: Obviously it's a really well recognised brand, and if you make a good impression on people with the right people and/or end up in a good team, you can get involved in quite interesting work.
cons:
Despite all the HR rhetoric around "we do everything, so you can have multiple career paths within the same company" the reality is that business need is absolute number 1, above investing in their people, developing logical approaches to client relationships etc. There's a huge disconnect between the product recruiters sell you (6 month rotations in different areas, develop your skills, opportunity for exposure to strategy work, analytics) is extremely different from the reality (a lot of need for technical or administrative grads, account partners are only interested in the skills you have and will keep you in a role for 12 months+ to use them).

Resource management is so convoluted that in practice the only way to get on to projects is to know the right people, which results in a bit of a "boys club" atmosphere on some accounts.

And obviously lots and lots of systems that you have to go through for everything from reclaiming expenses to trying to be promoted, none of which seem to integrate at all.

headline: 'It was the best of times - it was the worst of times.'
pros:
You can develop great autonomy and work out the best way you can contribute to the business or change the way you work. 

The resources for collaboration are considerable, and aren't limited to one's local geography; connecting with a pool of 300,000+ professionals all over the world is inspiring --- and humbling. 

You easily acquire pride in having those 3 iconic letters appearing in your employment profile.
cons:
One must maintain a sense of perspective at all times. I became emotionally involved with my work, the things I was doing and the feeling of total responsibility to the point of martyrdom. I failed to reach out to the available resources, to take a step back and see the "big picture". 

For a company like IBM, I cannot emphasise enough the importance of having moderate detachment, without sacrificing passion and enthusiasm. 

It is a balance not everyone can maintain.

headline: The Name of the Game is Stress
pros:
The people you work with are often great. They try their hardest and there is genuine teamwork that occurs. Even the managers are often nice, they certainly have human sides.  

McDonald’s will train you well. You will know how to deal with a variety of situations, cleaning will become second nature and your skills with either customers or food handling will be unparalleled. But there is a high price to pay for that.
cons:
McDonald’s runs on stress and threats. Every action you perform can have drastic consequences and if it does not meet the standards except to be reprimanded. Written warnings, vague open ended threats and even straight up verbal harassment. 

The system is set up to keep you stressed so you’re always performing fast and on the fly. But this constant stress takes its toll, especially outside of the workplace. Managers experience it the the worst, having unrelenting stress thrust upon them by the higher ups mandating all sorts of sales goals and timing. Profit comes at the cost of the people.

headline: This was definitely one of the worst work experience i've had!
pros: 50% discount, Friendly and down to earth staffs
cons: To be completely honest I was actually enjoying my time here, the staffs were very friendly and down to earth. The work I used to do there wasn't too bad either, even tho the company was quite unorganised, which meant late working hours. it wasn't necessarily a problem for me, I was handling it fine. My main problem was with the management, they had no sense of structure or understanding. I was working here as a graphic designer, for two and half months. They had only two graphic designers including me creating design's for more than 8 departments. It was slightly difficult at start as I had a terrible hand over with 2 day quick introductory training but managed to adjust fine within a week or so. I was creating artworks for 2017 for the buyers who were going through several stages of range reviews. After seeing that nearly 80% of my work was selected in these range reviews I was extremely excited to feel I was having positive impact on the company. Was constantly reaching out to the buyers asking for feedback and whether or not if they felt supported by the work I was creating, had every strong feedback from "HARDGOODS" department as they felt "this was the strongest year they had for designs". "MENSWEAR" stated that they were "one stage ahead from last year in terms of designs". So everything was going great until just a week before my probation period was coming to an end. I was handed a letter while in middle of work, for probation review. With comments stating "Poor Communication", "Missing deadlines", "Bad Management" and was called to a meeting. I was just shocked and just devastated, as I felt these were very unfair statements. I collected as much evidence I could to try and defend myself from these comments, printed out my selected designs, deadline spreadsheets then went to the meeting. Sat down as my manager made claims of me missing deadlines, poor communication and poor management therefore we will have to let you go. She kept the comments very vague as possible and as she finished speaking. I asked if she would kindly expand on where exactly I missed the deadline to which she said oh I just heard alot of buyers saying that. I asked for specific's but she changed the subject to "Poor Communication". She stated that she overheard me asking more than few question to the buyers and wasting their time not understanding what they needed, which I found was outrageous comment to make. But I responded by admitting yea out of all the things you have claimed, you are probably right to a extent about the fact I may have asked more than one questions sometimes. But it was in the beginning as I was still trying to adjust and it was genuine questions for area's I didn't understand fully. Since when is it wrong to ask questions? But then again I can show you evidence right in front of me that more than 80% of designs that I've created has been selected by "yourself" along with other managers in the range review and has had positive feedbacks. Surely that at-least proves that I was understanding what you wanted and delivering?, she completely ignored my request for an opportunity to try and prove myself and just took the conversation around in circle still keeping it extremely vague. So I knew that I would not get anywhere with this and looked over to the guy from "HR" who was next to her and asked if I will get an opportunity for an appeal. As I found this very unfair, and all due respect to her i feel i've been falsely accused and even if we say for the arguments sake that all these points were true. Why wasn't I confronted about this earlier? surely everyone deserve's at least one opportunity to know where they were falling behind on and to see if they can act improve on those points. this is the second meeting i've had, the first one was completely positive. The manager made snarky comment from the side saying we are a fast moving company and I am usually really busy so don't really get the time to confront all employees, its you who should have arranged a meeting with me and asked. Just another outrageous comment from her, I honestly wanted to say "are you sure it's me that needs to work on my management skills?" but yea tried not to go down to her level. Spoke to the HR guy later, he stated he will send me an appeal letter within a week for an opportunity to make my case. Well now its 2 and half weeks, nothing whatsoever. I emailed them kindly requesting an update which was completely ignored. Again to be frankly honest I wouldn't have worked there even if there was a positive outcome from my appeal as I wouldn't mentally feel comfortable going back to that environment, I just wanted to state my case and at lest defined myself from this accusation. Anyway sorry for my long rant, hopefully my experience will be some help to some of you.
